commentBody: This is one of those themes I had to look up after I finished the puzzle. Clever, I guess, but a bit of a stretch.

Very entertaining and very easy.
Thank you, David.

Easy Week continues.
Finished this one well under average time, then had to read the column to figure out the conceit. It seems I know trivia and minutiae but need to work on my logic and problem-solving skills.

I was pondering the clue for 8D and suddenly‚Ä¶

I saw ESAU!

Wow!  What a tight theme and great fill. 

Thanks, David, for a super Thursday, and thanks, Deb, for a solid explainer!
Had to do two lookups, but got the themed entries with a lot of crosses. Clever theme, and a fun puzzle!

Wow. Got the happy music, but had to come to the column to see what it all meant. I understood substituting ‚Äúall‚Äù for money, but the only currency I recognized was RIAL and RAND.  Now I know! 

Thanks, David, for a very enjoyable puzzle.

I found this puzzle right on the money, although the revealer didn‚Äôt help me solve the puzzle.  Only after completing the puzzle did I spot the embedded currencies (some of which were unknown to me).

As always, I appreciated the musical answers (ELO, ONELOVE).  The revealer also had a musical connection as Money Changes Everything, is song by new wave band The Brains, made popular by Cindy Lauper‚Äôs cover version.
Great quiz! Now, Cyndi Lauper is my new earworm. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pp4suZ4jNXg&ab_channel=CyndiLauperVEVO

Brilliant. I solved it quickly knowing I had to insert the country currency. I knew something was missing and that I needed to change the currency to something else for everything to make sense, but I did not realize that i had to use an alternative to ‚Äúeverything‚Äù.
Another one I completed, then checked Wordplay to see what it all was about.
Why would Olympic divers be proud of those any more so than any other athlete?
That was amazing.  Loved the opening ACID/BASE duo for the open.

Wonderful theme!!!

I didn't think it was nearly as easy as others.  But then again I'm not nearly as smart as others.
though a little too cute for me, still a mostly enjoyable solve. I got the theme, but realized I didn't know enough currencies to fill it in so it was no help lol

Oh I liked this ... I left the theme clues blank at first, but once the crosses had given me STANDTRIAL -- and I knew rial was currency -- that gave me the MONEY part of the revealer, it all clicked. (Or, should I say, it dollar clicked?) Turns out I didn't have a clue what currency Costa Rica uses. Also had roam before ROVE, but "mn_ user" seemed unlikely; else before ISNT, but I was sure enough of MINORIN that I deleted the across. And I would have guessed UCLA but decided I wasn't sure enough of the answer... Love the clue for NERD. And having sung Carmen (just in choir, but we did a semi-staged version with solos done by actual opera people), I really wanted TORERO to be-ador instead. Ah well. Also, now I have that going through my head -- https://youtu.be/YUBxaK9T5II

Naticked in the SE corner. EZER sitting on DEDE (now there‚Äôs an interesting image), with the American specific GRE to complete, left me without my usual ‚Äútry the most obvious‚Äù approach. Having UTILIsE for 42D didn‚Äôt help.

Finished within 15s of my average, but didn‚Äôt much care for it if I‚Äôm honest. It was too cute by half: a revealer split top middle, top right, bottom right, if you think about EVERYTHING as ALL, you can replace those letters with various currencies that you might trivially know and these fills will become other recognizable phrases that don‚Äôt relate to anything‚Ä¶

I don‚Äôt mean to be a grump. There was some good fill and cluing. I just felt jumbled by the theme.

The fill was pretty good, and there was nice symmetry with the revealer and theme answers.

Still too easy for a Thursday.

6/10.

Said the check to its owner, "Cash me if you can!"

(You can bank me later for this one.)

Spectacular concept ‚Äì not that I got ALL of it, only half. I danced around the grid, but once I got EVERYTHING and had the C in place, MONEY CHANGES EVERYTHING wrote itself. From there, I caught on to the currencies and changed "all" OVER to WON OVER. This should have tipped me off to the second ‚Äì and best‚Äì part of the gimmick. But I didn't take the time to stop and ponder. My loss! My mind is really blown by the creativity of this puzzle. Thank you, Mr. Kahn! I only wish I had done it justice and taken the time to think... (But one thing I do think of when I see MONEY in a puzzle is this: https://youtu.be/ETxmCCsMoD0?si=3JgX4sPwDSP8rVvC)

I thought the theme was clever but it's tough to suss out if you're not current with your currencies. Crossers were fairly generous, though I thought the SE was somewhat tricky. Far from the worst Thursday I've done but not particularly memorable either.

Not a bad puzzle. However, I needed help in the SE corner.

Even though I understood the theme, I did not know the currency of Costa Rica. I've never heard of EZER Weizman: it's the prime minister who is the chief of the executive branch of government there, so if I know Isreaeli politicians, its the PMs rather than the presidents, much like with Germany. DEDE (what kind of name is that?) Allen was a mystery, too. I would never have figured out "That's the pits!" (a phrase I understand) solves to UGH. The clues for RETITLE, UTILIZED and HES, especially, were just not on my wavelength. Also, it appears I will never remember who takes which American exam. I *know* GRE is an exam, but not who it is for.

So yeah, I looked up the president, the editor, and I checked the column for GRE and RETITLE - that gave me crosses to deal with the rest of the SE section on my own.

The crossing of T_EBO and SB_ was cruel for me, too, but suddenly TAEBO dawned on me - I must have seen it here before.

Also, MINOR IN I only got because of the years of contact with American culture. Over here we do it differently. All courses have a major focus. Students take many classes outside this main focus, too, but they may be all over the place. For example, a management student can take classes in singing, geography, art, and philosophy. These additional classes don't constitute a coherent, minor focus of the person's studies. And 25-30 years ago we didn't even have that: I studied law only.

Any puzzle with SULU in it is okay by me. A perfectly fine puzzle, though not really a Thursday. Anyways, fell down a rabbit hole with DEDE Allen, who had a very interesting life and career. Anyone interested in movie history should check out her Wikipedia entry. Besides Dog Day Afternoon, she also edited Bonnie and Clyde and Reds, among others. Here's the famous Attica scene from Dog Day Afternoon. https://youtu.be/lB6Gk5EtunI?si=COPn6VhhDhzJq1N_

The revealer should have been: money changes all.
That would have been a fairer challenge.

Too tired to read the column. Maybe I‚Äôll suss out the theme in the morning. Easy solve, but the theme escapes me. And a pox on Harry Potter and Star Trek references. Never had any use for either one of them. Time to pass out. Happy puzzling

I solved the puzzler without a clue about what was happening with the money until very late in the game, but I never spotted the national currencies even then.  

A couple of clues were especially fun‚ÄîBrother hood, which I got right away, and Square one, which I didn't.  All in all, an enjoyable puzzle, but I'm worried that we're being set up for a killer Friday.  

Thank you, David Kahn, and I'm sure you'll keep up the good work without any help from me.  A hundred and ninety puzzles?? Words fail me.  Your head must be going a mile a minute, full tilt, all the time.

Whew. This one was very challenging for me, but eminently fair. Took me 84% longer than usual. Could be because I'm tired and would have done better in the morning. Still, I persisted and finally finished with no lookups. 

It was nice that the revealer came so early in the puzzle, so I knew the theme had to do with MONEY, but it took forever to get CHANGES and EVERYTHING, and I didn't know most of the currencies, so didn't understand what money had to do with the answers. Things started to click with WONOVER. I recognized WON as currency, but still didn't know what I was supposed to do with it. 

Forgot that Palladium was an element and kept trying to think of words for theater or ballroom, so that and a few others in the NE slowed me down. Didn't know the two names in the SE and had SAT instead of GRE for the longest time.

Once I finally figured out the NE and SE, the complete revealer "revealed" itself, and I caught on to the currency words replacing ALL to understand the theme.

Loved "Square one" for NERD.

And now I have Cyndi Lauper stuck in my head!

Here in the COLONIES, we ORDINARY people demand that MONEY should STAND TRIAL. We will not be WON OVER by any old FIREBRAND.

STAND TALL, ALLIES!  CHANGES are ALL OVER. Express your opinions, ORALLY and loudly, before a FIREBALL consumes EVERYTHING.
I loved this puzzle! Kudos to the author. Seemed like a refreshing return to hard Thursdays

Add me to the list of those who solved the "moneychanger" clues entirely through their crosses and required the Gameplay column to splain me what the theme is.
Feeling simultaneously dense (not TOO complex, after all), disappointed (uber-groany wordplay, if you ask me) and ultimately sanguine about the ease of this Thursday solve.

First, figure out the initial starred clue answer. Then replace the "all" with the name of the currency used in the indicated country, because "MONEY CHANGES EVERYTHING" and "EVERYTHING" is a synonym for "all."  ...Nope.  Sorry, that theme idea should have been sent back to bounce in the constructor's head for another long time.
Not all ACIDs [burn]. Consider the quantity of stearic acid we consume when eating a flavourful piece of nicely fatty steak.

I found the Eastern portion of the puzzle quite difficult today.    Having the proper nouns of  Phil, Ezer, and Dede made it tough, as did Colonies (I had cleaned the trick, but it didn't help me as I have never heard of the Costa Rican "Colon"before.   As to that who "is it" as a natural for to "isn't", and that Eastern bit took me forever becauseI refuse to do lookups on the Internet
Not for me.

Good theme. The rest not so much.
A bath room is not a loo. There is no bath in a loo.
Fresh and clever.

The theme was fun, and a good puzzle over all. And for the most part, I found it moderately easy, but "Square one" tripped me up! I only finished the puzzle when I gave up and entered the D for the last cross. Thank you Mr. Aronow for including that one in your "tough clues" -- I was completely unable to read that clue as anything other than "the first step".
Woof.
What a fun puzzle. Very clever theme.
The SE was a bit of a bear, and the theme a little harder than average to get, but I liked it.  Solve time 18% longer than average.
A perfect Thursday puzzle!

Yes DENALI, DENALI, DENALI!  

I said it out loud, 
I wrote it down, 
then I said it again for good measure!  

Nyah, nyah, you can't stop me!
I‚Äôm certain I‚Äôll be sorry I asked, but how is WONOVER ‚ÄúUbiquitously.‚Äù?

Fantastic.

This would have been a much 
different and less satisfying solve
if the currencies were more familiar.

I was expecting a euro, peso, dollar, or loon!

Gave me *just* the right amount of crunch.

Boring fact about me- 
I have a terrible fear of moths.
Butterflies, slightly less so, 
but they also FLIT about so‚Ä¶

Now you know.

Happy Thursday all! 
The Friday of Fridays!

Very enjoyable puzzle with a fun little twist.  

I completed the "fill in the boxes" portion first, then went back for the puzzle.  

I groaned, I smiled.  

What more can I ask?
I'm all in.
Not my cup of tea. But, I was able to get it all with Wordplay. Thanks for the hints. Happy Thursday!

Even after solving the whole puzzle, I did not understand what was going on with the starred clues until I read the explanation here. For the first starred clue that I solved, STAND TRIAL, I thought "of course, money changes everything if you stand trial, since you can afford good lawyers!". But the same logic did not apply to the others. :-)

This one stretched definitions a little too far for my liking.  While technically you could call a person bringing a lawsuit a ‚Äúsuer‚Äù, as a legal professional, I have never (in 20+ years) heard that word used. In the context of seeking damages, you could bring a (law)suit, and the person doing so would be called the ‚Äúplaintiff‚Äù, or ‚Äúcomplainant‚Äù, or ‚Äúpetitioner‚Äù, or, if it went far enough, even the ‚Äúappellant‚Äù.

I have read all of the comments (including a very heated discussion on geopolitics üòµ‚Äçüí´) and I still don't get RETITLE. Is it just that if you title something you call it something?

Other than that I enjoyed the mental workout.
This is one of those days where I give extra respect to the people who don‚Äôt use autocheck for these puzzles. I am definitely not one of those people.

Well... managed to work this one out with some look-ups and a whole lot of working the crosses, but must admit that I never entirely caught on to the trick. That's all on me. Pretty amazing feat of construction. And... my usual puzzle find. A Monday from June 11, 2012 by Andrea Carla Michaels and Michael Blake. I guess you could call this an AEIOU puzzle. Theme answers: FALLENIDOL FELLOWSHIP FILLINTHEBLANKS FOLLOWSUIT FULLNELSON Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/11/2012&g=33&d=D I'll shut up now. ...

A few poor clue / answer pairings today. SUER is not a thing. HES as a plural is not a thing. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the pits‚Äù for UGH was pretty weak. And the EZER / DEDE sandwich was absurd with citations of humans no one had heard of. I solved without assistance because Ms. Allen has been misused this way before, but not without a lot of grumbling.

It‚Äôs inspiring to me.  Here‚Äôs a constructor with nearly 190 NYT puzzles, his first published 31 years ago ‚Äì still coming up with fresh, crackling ideas.  Still working hard, excited about making new puzzles (i.e., he says in his notes that how to play out the trick behind today‚Äôs puzzle is something that bounced around in his head for a long time).  

So there‚Äôs that.  There‚Äôs also his cluing.  When I‚Äôm making a puzzle and trying to clue an answer, I often look and see what clues have been made before, and David‚Äôs clues so often have fresh angles. Even today, ESAU has appeared in the major outlets more than 600 times, but never using ‚Äúthe sauna‚Äù motif.

In addition, there‚Äôs his skill in crafting a grid.  Today‚Äôs puzzle required a mammoth 64 theme squares but is filled smooth as silk, and design gorgeously accommodates the complicated theme.

So, yes, this puzzle, with its tricky layered theme, provided a splendid outing for me, and I‚Äôm grateful for that, David.  But thank you as well for the inspiring example you set.

It took me a while to see the theme. At least it didn't require doing Laplace transforms of differential equations using hexadecimal interpretations of highlighted squares as coefficients. Although that was part of the trial-and-error process for me.

Brilliant construction, with eight thematic elements, seven of which were quite lengthy. Very clever theme, with various currencies replacing ALL to transform entries, since MONEY CHANGES EVERYTHING. Discerned the theme very early, which helped make this an easy puzzle for me. Still took me 18 minutes to get everything filled in. EZER and DEDE were unknowns, but were completely provided by the four verticals. Puzzle of the year material here!

Not to be a yeller, but the suer might want a retitler.


But the puzzle?
This one was money, maker.

Very tight theme.
Enjoyed it greatly.
I agree that the bottom right had some unknown names stacked (EZER is completely new to me.) But as mentioned, the cross clues sorted them out.
I also agree that HES and SUER aren‚Äôt really great, but UGH was a fantastic answer.

Over all, a top-flight puzzle
The SE corner was certainly bumpy, but the kicker for me is that I figured out the theme and found it entertaining... but needed to look up two of the currencies involved to help myself out.

I got the money part of the theme and thought that was nice and all but was like ‚ÄúWON OVER for ubiquitously? What a bad clue.‚Äù  I solved the puzzle scratching my head as to the other themed answers. Then I read the column. Totally missed the subtle part of the theme but ü§Ø. Nice puzzle.

Awesome theme, I really enjoyed that.  And thank you, editors ... DOYEN would be meh and even though I worked in in FX for years I would have had to look up Armenia ü§î.   An extra thumbs up for no rap trivia.

Nice one today.  I was scratching my head and muttering until I got the "down" word of the theme, and that changed everything.  Very little trivia, which was nice, and that was all solvable by intersecting clues.  More like this one, please.

Early bafflement made me decide just to doodle around, looking for sure-fire entries and smart-alecky clues until I got enough letters to suss out a word, whether it seemed sensible or not.
I was hampered by the names of film folk and coach, though ORR is always a good guess for anything hockey-related.  

One doesn't see TORERO nearly as often as 'toreador' though I once read a novel that stressed that as the proper term...I took it out early on and put it back when the nickel dropped.  
TIL the Costa Rican monetary unit.  Surprised!
And suddenly, it was ALL done.

Aside:   I have a Korean bill from the 1950's (Dad sent us each one) and that is NOT how the currency is spelt on that note.

Curiosity is my favorite emotion to be gotten from a crossword puzzle.  Challenge is great, but challenge can sometimes be painful.  Curiosity is always delicious.

I was immensely curious when I read the theme clues.  What on earth did the country have to do with its clue?

But my curiosity didn't last very long.  I had MONEY at the top; I saw that STAND TRIAL was coming in; and I saw that STAND TALL was the right answer to the STAND TRIAL clue.  Aha!  That means that the phrase is MONEY IS ALL.

It's not -- it's MONEY CHANGES EVERYTHING, which I've actually never heard said or seen written --  but it doesn't matter.  The trick is the same, and the right words in the phrase will come in soon enough.

What a beautifully conceived and executed puzzle!  Sheer perfection.  Well, except for the SW corner with its grp, director's name, song title, and Harry Potter clue.  I thought I'd crash and burn there -- until I came up with COWL which somehow bailed me out.  CAMERON (he was "Titanic", right?) came in and I realized NERD was the answer to "Square one" -- a clue that fools me every time.

Loved this puzzle!  I'm writing it down as a POY possibility.
This one was on the money!

I'd like to say that this puzzle was right on the MONEY for me, but, alas, it was not my cup of tea. It's not that it was difficult.  I solved it fairly quickly.  Perhaps too quickly.

I figured out the three-part revealer almost immediately upon reading the clue, and I saw that all of the themed answers had foreign currency in them, but it wasn't until I was finished with the puzzle, and had the time to look again at the themed answers and their "irregular" clues that I saw that the currencies needed to be replaced with "all" to make sense of the clues.

When I "get it" only after the solve is completed, and my reaction is, "Yeah, I see, but..."  Well, these puzzles aren't the most satisfying.
Not that I hated it; just not my cup of tea.

However, as ever, I'm terribly impressed with the cleverness of the puzzle-maker.  I'm always amazed at how they come up with themes like this and find original answers.
I‚Äôve spent so much time working closely with Brits over the years that I had come to UTILIZE UTILISE as natural, so I had to stare at 42D for a long time before swapping in the Z to hear the music.

Very nice theme, even though, as other's said, the very SE corner was a mess with two mega obscure word jumble names.

I was thrown off by TORERO - only ever heard these guys called matadors or bullfighters in English, so would have expected an answer which was the Spanish for something to have a language clue in the clueing.

Nice theme. Like others, I found the SE difficult, with two unknown names crossing an unknown initialism. (There seems to be an infinite supply of American exam abbreviations.)
The killer for me was in the middle, with yet another unknown three-letter organization crossing a frankly implausible looking exercise regimen. Too many possible letters in that cross, and I couldn't be bothered to cycle through them.

But great fun up to that point...
Neither easy nor difficult, and no rebus!  As for Dede Allen, come on. I could see if she had just diied maybe.

"65A. A [Square one] is a NERD."

Thanks for that clarification. May I now ask why?

Surprised to see so much positive commentary today.

That was brutal for me. Very frustrating. Even after getting the revealer, I couldn‚Äôt grasp how to apply it to the theme answers, and a lot of the other clues were not on my wavelength.

Not a good performance for me today!
Odd thing: I just did a May 2005 puzzle from the archives, coincidentally also by David J. Kahn, and ANOINTS and EZER were in that one too. Saving up words to use every 20 years, maybe?

Group with a hit that included the lyrics

"EVERYTHING ALL the time"




Extra points if you can spell the producer's last name.
Very clever puzzle. I still didn't figure out the reason the countries were in the clues, so I came here to find that out.

The ingenuity of constructors astounds me.

That's why they earn the big colons! (enlarged?)


Although I could do without the image of the furry guy in the sauna. Breakfast test anymore?

Themeless Thursday for me.  Solved it. Stared at it.  Got mad at myself for STILL not getting the theme.  And then came here to read about it.  Any further comment I would make would be unfair to the constructor.  It's not his fault I couldn't see his theme.

Unless you happen to be well versed in the names of foreign currencies , this was a themeless Thursday.  
It‚Äôs impressive construction, but only after it‚Äôs explained to you.

after failing on the Tuesday (?!?!?) and Thursday 2wks ago i must say my confidence has been somewhat shaken, and when i completed my first pass through across & down i had so little to go on i was sure my 1week streak would be broken....but this was perfectly clued to what I've come to expect as Thursday difficulty, slow but steady progress over 55m got me the solve.
Excellent puzzle, clever, fun theme and brilliant execution. Loved it!
I like it when cryptic clues work their way into a regular crossword! (8 down)

Lots of fun. And I appreciated the effort all the more after trying to come up with an example of my own. No luck, but I did fantasize about the fury that would have resulted if I'd been able to do something with NGWEE (Zambia).
I knew most of the currencies and then remembered that COLON=Columbus.

What brilliant construction. Took me forever to figure out the needed substitution, and then the remainder of the puzzle fell. Well, once I took out 'asH' for the pit in the SE and realized that Hopper was not going to be some misremembered spelling for Hedda in the NW. 

Took almost as long as my Saturday usual, although that may be because when I figured out the theme, I had to pause and gaze back at each theme word in awe and appreciation before going on for the finish.
I almost forgot how much I hate HES as an answer. So ugly, so "not a plural any real person actually uses."
Theme aside, I found the clueing completely baffling. I wasn't anywhere near the wavelength of the constructor on this one. Can't remember the last time i struggled with a puzzle this much.
Solved in relatively good time, I think, and knew the currencies but didn‚Äôt recognize that ALL in the answers was replaced. Seriously clever puzzle.
18D so the mountain name reverted but they forgot about the National Park apparently.

I figured out that the answers to the starred clues were looking for currencies after getting ‚Äòmoney changes everything‚Äô.  But had to work around those clues together the answers bc who really knows all these currencies?? Korea? South Africa? Costa Rica?  C‚Äômon!! 
My daughter and I together got that each currency was replaced with the word all.  But still.  Clever but no way ordinary people even faithful crossword solvers know all those currencies

Popping in to say that the puzzle was a feat of construction *and* fun to solve, which, as ye other puzzling veterans will back me up, aren‚Äôt always synonymous. 

Also, I‚Äôm heartened to revisit the forum and see the ideological fray of earlier today deleted by the mods. NYT emus, you did right by Wordplay today.
Very cool!!

Lots of comments about HES. Did a search for that answer, and...

"Jolly good fellow" has been in the clue 46 times. Some other common clues included...

"... so fine."
"...all that." 
"...a real nowhere man."
"...just not that into you."
"...got the whole world in his Hands."

And lots of other variations. 

...

Wow, that was slick! I figured out that there would be a substitution gimmick early on (thank you Cyndi Lauper) but it took me a while to nail it down. Thanks also to my MINOR IN International Business, I knew all the currencies, except for the COLON. I thought the Ticos used the Dollar, actually.

55A was a surprise; I wondered if it might be one of the service academies, USMA or USNA, but I think those are harder to apply to, including getting a Congressional nomination. My cousin was accepted to Annapolis, but deferred to a NROTC scholarship to Carnegie-Mellon.
Troubled by the complete lack of shout-outs to Cyndi Lauper on display here.
Fun theme once I figured it out. Made me feel like a genius when I explained it to my mom and fianc√© and they both looked at me like I had three heads

It took me an embarrassingly long time to figure out that it was ALL that was being replaced everywhere....

And this was after I'd filled in MONEY CHANGES EVERYTHING.
Brilliant theme!  One of the best Thursday puzzles of the year.
My reaction to the southeast corner. https://youtu.be/wRnSnfiUI54?feature=shared
Easy-ish Thursday without getting the theme....but once theme was explained...really loved the ingenuity. Bravo David!
Thirty seven minutes. It was ALL I could handle.

Solved it once I clued into the hint (currency), but I didn't get the 'all' part until reading the write-up- wow, that takes it to a whole other level, and explains why the answers kind of worked, but not quite... thanks for the fun Thursday wordplay.

Awesome puzzle!
It was super satisfying going from completely bewildered by the theme, to noticing the currencies but still being bewildered by the clues, to getting the revealer phrase but still not clicking, to the penny finally dropping!
Very clever and lots of fun - many thanks David!
I figured out to fit currency into these answers, but the "trick" is not that amusing to me, even after reading the column. Oh well.
Wow, what a great puzzle! Congrats to the constructor. I really smiled when I finally got the theme and enjoyed the puzzle a lot! Thank you!
A Thursday & not a rebus among us. Clever theme which, as usual, I did not get till after solving.
Clever puzzle. Didn't get the theme till I read the explanation though ü§£

Great multilevel twister of a theme. Always nice when the light dawns in time for it to be helpful.

Not a big fan of pronouns as answers (HES) when they don‚Äôt refer to specific persons (or, I guess, animals). And pluralizing ‚Äúhe‚Äù adds to the discomfort, despite its being a legit word as noted by others.

That was my only nitpick. Otherwise this was a beaut!
Really impressive but if construction, second excellent Thursday in a row. SE corner was a bit muddy but overall a very satisfying solve
Feel silly to ask, but how is  ‚ÄúRetitle‚Äù the answer to ‚ÄúCall, again?‚Äù ?

I don‚Äôt have a deep knowledge of world currencies, so for me this ended up being a themeless Thursday. The trick is sorta clever but my ultimate reaction was a shrug. I‚Äôve seen way better substitution puzzles. For example last Thursday‚Äôs double negatives. What I did appreciate is that now I have the song ‚ÄúMoney Changes Everything‚Äù in my head. Written by Tom Gray and made famous as the opening track on Cyndi Lauper‚Äôs She‚Äôs So Unusual.

Loved this one!  Jampacked with punny but very fair clues, and MONEY CHANGES EVERYTHING came pretty quickly based on the clue and the partial fills, then it was just a question of grokking the gimmick.  Get one, get them all.  It must have been very tricky to find phrases or words containing national currencies which, when you replace the currency word with the letters ALL, still makes a valid word or phrase.

I mean who *thinks* of something like this, then actually is able to *execute* it?

I guess, someone who has written 189 previous NYT crosswords!

Hats off to the constructor and here's to reaching 200.

Not current with foreign currency ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èüí∞ so ended up having to look up each but had fun with it. This certainly was no ORDINARY puzzle üò¨. Originally had ISIT at 34A knew PHIL & CAMERON but no idea on DEDE. This puzzle had some fun ELEMENTS üéâüëè
Well, thank my lucky stars I happen to know a fair amount of different currencies from my ‚ÄúUseless trivia but maybe someday Jeopardy‚Äù mental vault! Very fun, good times - a diving 10/10!

I finished the puzzle in typical Thursday time, but the theme went way way way over my head. Since the themes and clues didn't make sense (not uncommon on Thursdays), I relied pretty much 100% on crosses.

@Andrzej - A major field of study requires a certain number of credits and configuration of coursework to attain a degree. There is room - not much in the first year or two, but more later - to study either more specially or more variedly as the student wishes and the academic adviser allows. But a true academic minor involves being committed to and permitted to satisfy the minimal requirements of a second field of study, usually but not necessarily related to the major.
This is different from a dual-degree, where a student is fully enrolled in a program to satisfy all the requirements of two different degrees. Dual degree programs usually take at least another year and have strict standards about the student‚Äôs progress. A person who wanted to go into music entrepreneurship might get a B.Mus. and a B.A. in business in a dual-degree program.

@Jane W.

I think "restroom" comes from our aversion to explicitly mentioning bodily functions.  We use "restroom" more commonly in public settings, where we don't expect a bathtub or shower to be part of the setup, and if we are talking about the full setup in a private home, we might call it either a restroom or a bathroom, depending on one's preferences.

Counting how many such facilities there are in a home is real estate lingo; a full bath contains a tub; a three-quarters bath (less commonly used) may imply a shower but no tub, a half bath is a powder room, with just a toilet and a sink, and (disgustingly) a quarter bath is just the toilet (I assume and hope there's a sink conveniently located in the vicinity).

Full bath and half bath have become ordinary vernacular here.

@Desert Dweller

Did you notice that the "provisional" solutions, as clued, each contained the letter sequence ALL?
So [How some medications are taken [Jordan]] clued ORALLY, but the "MONEY CHANGES EVERYTHING" theme told us we needed to replace the ALL (="everything") with the currency of Jordan, DINAR.
This gave the solution to be entered: OR(DINAR)Y. It doesn't need to be separately clued, because the method of construction is clearly specified; and, as a sanity check, the entered solution is also a valid word.

Once I deduced the trick, I was immediately able to solve the themed entries---I just needed to find a word containing ALL that conformed to the clue, replace those letters with the known currency name, and check that the result was also a valid word.

So, for me, the cluing was neat, clever, and helpful.
@Desert Dweller they gave you the country whose currency results in the modified answer. So to say that there was "no cluing for the modified answer" is just plain wrong.
